(Singing) I'm going to write me a letter I'm going to telephone Every time I want to...
This is Cassandra Wilson from her latest CD ""Loverly."" The idea here was to take standards from the classic American songbook.
Then she fused them with modern sonics, African rhythms, and of course, her own unique vocal style.
Wilson has been reimagining old standards since high school, except for a brief stint when she worked as an assistant public affairs director at a television station in New Orleans.
She told me that her career didn't really take off until the early 1980s when she found herself in New York, looking for yet another TV job.
My husband at the time, Anthony Wilson, was offered a job with his uncle in East Orange, New Jersey.
So I he had to travel with him.
And when we arrived, I tried to get another job in television because I thought that that's what I would be doing.

Well, when you go from a place like New Orleans to the Number One market in the world, it can be very difficult, and so I had the hardest time finding a job in television so I decided to start playing music again.
So I went out to a lot of jam sessions, met some musicians, and pretty soon, I was back into that whole scene.
What does it do to you when you go up on stage?
What do you feel like?
It's very exciting.
There's a rush.
It's a high.
I am thinking about - or feeling, rather, the audience.
There are great expectations.
There's great hope for what we're going to perform for the audience.
And there are a lot of feelings, and it's all very joyful.
(Soundbite of music)
Let's move to ""Loverly."" This album, to me, seems very much - it's leisurely, as well as loverly.
It's an album where you're taking your time with the songs.
How did you go about choosing the songs, first of all?
Really, we had no idea of what we were going to do.
And the musicians are of such a caliber that you bring them into a situation like that and you can call off, you know, just about any tune.
And because they're standards, everyone knows them.
And if they don't know them, they really can access them quickly.
(Soundbite of song ""Lover Come Back To Me"")
(Singing) I remember every little thing you used to do.
I'm so lonely.
Every road I walked along, I walked along with you.
No wonder I'm so lonely.
The sky was blue.
The night was cold.
The moon was new.
When love was old.
And while I'm waiting here, This heart of mine is singing Welcome.
Some people won't know them as standards, though.
I mean, some of - you have listeners of all ages and all backgrounds.
And if someone is coming to some of these songs fresh, they may not know very much about them.
What do you do to make your music appealing to both people who don't have a lot of music history and people who have listened to various versions of songs over many years?
Well, I think you have to make it very particular and very specific to the time.
And you also have to make it specific to how you feel about the song and what you want to emphasize in the piece.
And you can look at the harmonic structure of the song and, you know, make some changes there that are going to be interesting or fascinating for the musicians to perform.
And therefore, make it interesting for the audience.
I think the whole point is to, you know, it's win-win.
If you were happy about the music, then I think the audience picks that up and they feel that and they enjoy it, too.
Now, on this album, you have some percussion.
You have a Nigerian percussionist, and you have some ways of inserting African percussion into songs.
Tell me about your process of working with the percussion to try to shape some new sounds.
It was really great to work with Lekan Babalola.
I've known him for over 20 years.
He was the one really who suggested the use of African rhythmic patterns as the underpinning for most of the songs on ""Loverly.
(Soundbite of song ""Caravan""):
(Singing) In stars above that shine so bright.
The mystery of their fading light.
That shines above our caravan.
And I thought it was interesting, you know, and a great approach because when you think about jazz, you have to think about what the music was before Broadway.
You know, I tried to imagine what the music sounded like in the very beginning.
You know, what did the music of Congo Square sound like?
(Soundbite of song ""Caravan""):
(Singing) This is so exciting.
You are so inviting.
You know, all of these images came, and we just worked with those drums and worked with fashioning the pieces around that.
(Soundbite of song ""Caravan""):
(Singing) Of you beside me here beneath the view.
The song, ""Caravan,"" it sounds like you were really having a good time with that one.
Tell me about what that was like to record, why you chose it.

And very importantly, what Spain is going to do next, in terms of cleaning up the mess that it has in its banking system.
So far, it's been very slow to clean up that mess; to restructure its banks, to - you know, to write down the loans.
Behravesh says writing down the loans is not as easy as it may sound because a lot of the Spanish banks' debt holders are in Germany, and not interested in experiencing losses.
And while the bailout is aimed at shoring up Spanish banks, it comes from the EU as a loan to the Spanish government.
That's what investors are most worried about, says Behravesh.
What this bailout does is, in effect, it increases Spanish government debt.
So it's not a costless bailout for Spain.
Behravesh says the bailout could boost Spanish government debt by around 10 percent.
Peter Boockvar, equity strategist and portfolio manager at Miller Tabak, says that's the basic problem.
Even if the bailout money adds capital to Spanish banks, a huge part of the banks' assets are Spanish government bonds.
And, Boockvar points out, those bonds fell in value today after the bailout was announced.
So while Spanish banks may soon have more capital, if the Spanish sovereign bond market deteriorates further, well, that's going to impair the Spanish bond holdings of the Spanish banks.
And, he says, that sets up an inevitable downward spiral.
Boockvar says the markets did gain last week, when a deal between the EU and Spain was first telegraphed.
But that enthusiasm evaporated today as reality set in.
The market likes bailouts.
They like the short-term putting out of fire.
But as we've seen in - whether it's in the U.S.
or afterwards, in Europe over the past five years - is that it doesn't really solve the long-term problem of too much debt, not enough growth.
Boockvar says it's a short-lived Band-Aid, largely aimed at getting the markets past the Greek elections on Sunday.
The bailout will be useful if Greek voters support parties that reject their austerity program.
That would increase the odds of a messy Greek exit from the euro.
At least the Spanish banks have this backstop so we can hopefully, contain any Greek issue to within Greece.
Jim Paulsen, chief equity strategist at Wells Capital Management says, the Spanish bank bailout announced today is far from the final step in ending the euro crisis.
But Paulsen says he's beginning to view the dangers of Europe less as a financial contagion that could bring down the world, and more like simply a drag on growth.
And what really is going to matter is if the U.S.
economy's holding together or not - because if it is, then you got a pretty cheap market here.
And the U.S.
market got even a little cheaper today for buyers who might be tempted as all the major stock averages fell.
John Ydstie, NPR News, Washington.
In such a poor country, Haiti's buildings were simply not built to withstand a powerful earthquake.
NPR's Christopher Joyce talked to Haiti's only earthquake engineer.
When he was studying engineering in Haiti, Pierre Fouche's professors told him that at least one building there would survive an earthquake: the National Palace.
The palace now lies in ruins.
Fouche is getting his doctorate in earthquake engineering at the University of Buffalo.
He says as far as he knows, he's Haiti's only earthquake engineer.
Fouche says his family has survived, but he's saddened by the fact that so many that didn't were killed because buildings in Haiti are so poorly constructed.
